value.name: GetModelbreaches
value.description:
Returns information about Darktrace "modelbreaches" sometimes referred to as "model breaches", models or alerts.
A modelbreach will occur when something unusual has occurred, it will have a score and also a category which are used in combination to represent how important the alert is to triage.





https://[instance]/modelbreaches?pbid=123&historicmodelonly=true


https://[instance]/modelbreaches?from=2020-02-03T00:00:00&to=2020-02-9T23:59:59&minimal=true&includeacknowledged=true


https://[instance]/modelbreaches?did=1&starttime=1577836800000&minscore=0.6

It's very important to use parameters minimal=true unless lots of detail is required and fulldevicedetails=true if you're particularly interested in the involved devices.
value.descriptionForModel:
Returns information about Darktrace "modelbreaches" sometimes referred to as "model breaches", models or alerts.
A modelbreach will occur when something unusual has occurred, it will have a score and also a category which are used in combination to represent how important the alert is to triage.





https://[instance]/modelbreaches?pbid=123&historicmodelonly=true


https://[instance]/modelbreaches?from=2020-02-03T00:00:00&to=2020-02-9T23:59:59&minimal=true&includeacknowledged=true


https://[instance]/modelbreaches?did=1&starttime=1577836800000&minscore=0.6

It's very important to use parameters minimal=true unless lots of detail is required and fulldevicedetails=true if you're particularly interested in the involved devices.
examplePrompts: Get Darktrace alerts for the last week
Get the 10 most severe darktrace detections
Has darktrace seen a breach for this?
GET the information for model breach pbid=123 with information about the model at the time of breach only:
List all modelbreaches - including acknowledged breaches - for the 7 day period from 3rd to 9th February 2020:
Find model breaches for the device with did=1 since January 1st 2020 with a breach score above 60%:

inputs.name: count
inputs.description: Specifies the maximum number of items to return.

inputs.name: did
inputs.description: Identification number of a device modelled in the Darktrace system.

inputs.name: expandenums
inputs.description: True Strongly Recommended. Expand numeric enumerated types to their descriptive string representation.

inputs.name: from
inputs.description: Start time of data to return in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format.

inputs.name: to
inputs.description: End time of data to return in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format.

inputs.name: historicmodelonly
inputs.description: True Strongly Recommended. Return the JSON for the historic version of the model details only, rather than both the historic and current definition.

inputs.name: includeacknowledged
inputs.description: Include acknowledged breaches in the data.

inputs.name: includebreachurl
inputs.description: Recommended. Return a URL for the model breach in the long form of the model breach data, this requires that the FQDN configuration parameter is set.

inputs.name: minscore
inputs.description: Return only breaches with a minimum score. 0 - 1 e.g. high scoring would be 0.9

inputs.name: responsedata
inputs.description: When given the name of a top-level field or object, restricts the returned JSON to only that field or object.

inputs.name: pbid
inputs.description: Only return the model breach with the specified ID.

value.name: GetModelbreachCommentsBy{pbid}
value.description:
Returns comments made on specific Darktrace "modelbreaches" sometimes referred to as "model breaches", models or alerts.
A modelbreach indicates something unusual has occurred, it will have a score and also a category which are used in combination to represent how important the alert is to triage. Darktrace users add comments to give more context or information.

The `pbid` must be specified as part of the extension in the format: `/modelbreaches/[pbid]/comments`.
value.descriptionForModel:
Returns comments made on specific Darktrace "modelbreaches" sometimes referred to as "model breaches", models or alerts.
A modelbreach indicates something unusual has occurred, it will have a score and also a category which are used in combination to represent how important the alert is to triage. Darktrace users add comments to give more context or information.

The `pbid` must be specified as part of the extension in the format: `/modelbreaches/[pbid]/comments`.
examplePrompts: Get comments for the model breach with pbid 1234".
Get comments for this modelbreach.
Has anyone added any comments on that Darktrace alert?

inputs.name: pbid
inputs.description: Return the modelbreach comments for the specified ID.

inputs.name: responsedata
inputs.description: When given the name of a top-level field or object, restricts the returned JSON to only that field or object.

settings.QueryInputs:responsedata:Type:Name: String
settings.QueryInputs:responsedata:Name: responsedata
settings.QueryInputs:responsedata:Description: When given the name of a top-level field or object, restricts the returned JSON to only that field or object.
settings.PathInputs:pbid:Type:Name: Int32
settings.PathInputs:pbid:Name: pbid
settings.PathInputs:pbid:Description: Return the modelbreach comments for the specified ID.

value.name: GetDevices
value.description:
The devices endpoint is most useful when you know the darktrace device identifier or "did".
It retrieves information known about that device.

The devices endpoint did parameter can be provided as a comma separated list of each did e.g. /devices?did={device id 1},{device id 2}. When using this comma separated did parameter the return value will be a response of an array with each devices information.

Examples:


GET https://[instance]/devices?did=1234&includetags=true #note that used include tags as we want as much device info as possible


https://[instance]/devices?did=9


https://[instance]/devices?seensince=3600
value.descriptionForModel:
The devices endpoint is most useful when you know the darktrace device identifier or "did".
It retrieves information known about that device.

The devices endpoint did parameter can be provided as a comma separated list of each did e.g. /devices?did={device id 1},{device id 2}. When using this comma separated did parameter the return value will be a response of an array with each devices information.

Examples:


GET https://[instance]/devices?did=1234&includetags=true #note that used include tags as we want as much device info as possible


https://[instance]/devices?did=9


https://[instance]/devices?seensince=3600
examplePrompts: Tell me about device 1234
What is the ip for device 9 ?
GET a list of all the devices seen in the last hour
Determine the likely owner of the device with MAC address "AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF" in Darktrace by analyzing its usage patterns and associated services.
Can you identify the owner of the device with IP address 8.8.8.8 in Darktrace based on its activity patterns and associated user accounts?

inputs.name: did
inputs.description: Identification number of a device modelled in the Darktrace system.

inputs.name: ip
inputs.description: IP of the device modelled in the Darktrace system.

inputs.name: iptime
inputs.description: Returns the device which had the IP at a given time.

inputs.name: mac
inputs.description: Returns the device with this MAC address.

inputs.name: seensince
inputs.description: Relative offset for activity. Devices with activity in the specified time period are returned. The format is either a number representing a number of seconds before the current time, or a number with a modifier such as second, minute, hour day or week (Minimum=1 second).

inputs.name: sid
inputs.description: Identification number of a subnet modelled in the Darktrace system.

inputs.name: count
inputs.description: The number of devices to return. Only limits the number of devices within the current timeframe.

inputs.name: includetags
inputs.description: Whether to include tags applied to the device in the response.

inputs.name: responsedata
inputs.description: When given the name of a top-level field or object, restricts the returned JSON to only that field or object.

value.name: SearchDevices
value.description:
The devicesearch endpoint is most useful when you want to search for multiple devices and do not know the darktrace device identifier "did".
Multiple queries can be space-separated, for example `query=tag:"*T*" label:"Test"` or `query=type:"laptop" type:"desktop"`. Repeated field filters are treated as "or".
The default time frame is four weeks (28 days). This can be altered with the `seensince` parameter.

Examples:


https://[instance]/devicesearch?query="sarah"&orderBy=lastSeen&order=asc #note the orderBy and order parameters will make this result more useful as it'll show recently active ones first.


https://[instance]/devicesearch?count=10&query=tag:"Antigena*"%20ip:"10.0.1.*"


https://[instance]/devicesearch?count=100&query=ip:"8.8.8.8"

Try to ensure you use the count parameter whenever a large list of devices is likely else too much information will be returned
value.descriptionForModel:
The devicesearch endpoint is most useful when you want to search for multiple devices and do not know the darktrace device identifier "did".
Multiple queries can be space-separated, for example `query=tag:"*T*" label:"Test"` or `query=type:"laptop" type:"desktop"`. Repeated field filters are treated as "or".
The default time frame is four weeks (28 days). This can be altered with the `seensince` parameter.

Examples:


https://[instance]/devicesearch?query="sarah"&orderBy=lastSeen&order=asc #note the orderBy and order parameters will make this result more useful as it'll show recently active ones first.


https://[instance]/devicesearch?count=10&query=tag:"Antigena*"%20ip:"10.0.1.*"


https://[instance]/devicesearch?count=100&query=ip:"8.8.8.8"

Try to ensure you use the count parameter whenever a large list of devices is likely else too much information will be returned
examplePrompts: GET a list of devices that could be owned by "sarah"
GET a list of 10 devices with any "Antigena" tag in the subnet 10.0.1.0/24
Has darktrace seen a laptop with the ip 8.8.8.8 ?

inputs.name: count
inputs.description: The number of devices to return. If unspecified, defaults to 100.

inputs.name: orderBy
inputs.description: Orders the response by the specified filter, default value is `lastSeen`. Valid values are `priority`, `hostname`, `ip`, `macaddress`, `vendor`, `os`, `firstSeen`, `lastSeen`, `devicelabel` or `typelabel`.

inputs.name: order
inputs.description: Sets the sort order for returned devices as ascending or descending, can take `asc` or `desc`. Default is ascending.

inputs.name: query
inputs.description: An optional string search. Can query all fields or take a specific field filter from `label`, `tag`, `type`, `hostname`, `ip`, `mac`, `vendor` and `os`.

inputs.name: offset
inputs.description: An offset for the results returned.

inputs.name: seensince
inputs.description: Relative offset for activity. Devices with activity in the specified time period are returned. The format is either a number representing a number of seconds before the current time, or a number with a modifier such as second, minute, hour day or week (Minimum=1 second).

inputs.name: responsedata
inputs.description: When given the name of a top-level field or object, restricts the returned JSON to only that field or object.

settings.QueryInputs:order:Type:Name: String

settings.QueryInputs:offset:Description: An offset for the results returned.

value.name: GetRespondActions
value.description:
The `/antigena` endpoint returns information about current and past Darktrace RESPOND/Network (formerly Antigena Network) actions. It can be used to retrieve a list of currently quarantined devices or Darktrace RESPOND Actions requiring approval. Information from active integrations such as firewalls is not included in this data.

If a time window is not specified, the request will return all current actions with a **future expiry date** and all historic actions with an **expiry date in the last 14 days**. Actions which were not activated will still be returned.
value.descriptionForModel:
The `/antigena` endpoint returns information about current and past Darktrace RESPOND/Network (formerly Antigena Network) actions. It can be used to retrieve a list of currently quarantined devices or Darktrace RESPOND Actions requiring approval. Information from active integrations such as firewalls is not included in this data.

If a time window is not specified, the request will return all current actions with a **future expiry date** and all historic actions with an **expiry date in the last 14 days**. Actions which were not activated will still be returned.
examplePrompts: What actions has Darktrace taken?
Are any devices being actions by Darktrace RESPOND?
Are any devices being quarantined?

inputs.name: fulldevicedetails
inputs.description: Returns the full device detail objects for all devices referenced by data in an API response. Use   of this parameter will alter the JSON structure of the API response for certain calls.

inputs.name: includecleared
inputs.description: Returns all Darktrace RESPOND actions including those already cleared. Defaults to false.

inputs.name: includehistory
inputs.description: Include additional history information about the action state, such as when it was created or extended.

inputs.name: needconfirming
inputs.description: Filters returned Darktrace RESPOND actions by those that need human confirmation or do not need human confirmation.

inputs.name: from
inputs.description: Start time of data to return in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format.

inputs.name: to
inputs.description: End time of data to return in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format.

inputs.name: includeconnections
inputs.description: Adds a connections object which returns connections blocked by a Darktrace RESPOND action.

inputs.name: responsedata
inputs.description: When given the name of a top-level field or object, restricts the returned JSON to only that field or object.

inputs.name: pbid
inputs.description: Only return the Darktrace RESPOND actions created as a result of the model breach with the specified ID.

value.name: GetIncidentGroups
value.description:
An AI Analyst group serves as a container for an incident. Use this endpoint to obtain top-level information about detected incidents and filter them based on the available parameters. Groups have an identifier called "groupid" that starts with the 'g' character (e.g., g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633) and is 37 characters long. Groups consist of events, each with a unique "uuid" identifier, one of which will always be the "groupid" without the 'g' at the beginning (e.g., 04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633).

AI Analyst incidents are an excellent starting point for threat hunting or identifying active threats, as their purpose is to autonomously investigate lower-level alerts, anomalies, and unusual behavior.

**Note:** The timestamps and groupid provided in the examples are for illustration purposes only. Replace them with the appropriate timestamps and groupid based on your specific requirements. Make sure Unix timestamps for `starttime` and `endtime` correct for the time period you desire, as this is a common area to make a mistake. In the example URLs, replace `[instance]` with your actual instance information.

Use Cases:







### Examples:

1. GET all AI Analyst incidents in the last 24 hours (replace the example timestamps with your desired time range):

```
https://[instance]/aianalyst/groups?starttime=1646092800000&endtime=1646179200000&includegroupurl=true
```

2. GET all critical AI Analyst incidents for the 7-day period from 1st to 7th March 2022 (replace the example timestamps with your desired time range):

```
https://[instance]/aianalyst/groups?starttime=1646092800000&endtime=1646611200000&includeallpinned=false&critical=true&includegroupurl=true
```

3. GET details of an AI Analyst incident with groupid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633 in French (replace the example groupid with your desired groupid and locale with your preferred language):

```
https://[instance]/aianalyst/groups?groupid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633&locale=fr_FR&includegroupurl=true
```

4. GET details of suspicious SaaS incidents with a minimum score of 70 in the last 7 days (replace the example parameters with your desired values):

```
https://[instance]/aianalyst/groups?suspicious=true&saasonly=true&minscore=70&includegroupurl=true
```

Groups have an identifier called "groupid" that starts with the 'g' character (e.g., g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633) and is 37 characters long. AI Analyst incidents are an excellent starting point for threat hunting or identifying active threats, as their purpose is to autonomously investigate lower-level alerts, anomalies, and unusual behavior.

```

3. GET details of an AI Analyst incident with groupid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633 in French (replace the example groupid with your desired groupid and locale with your preferred language):

examplePrompts: What incidents has Darktrace detected?
Show me incidents with a score higher than 90.
List AI Analyst Incidents from the past 24 hours.
Find any incidents involving a device with ID 1500.
List incidents associated with subnet ID 200.
Are there any AI Analyst incidents with the unique identifier "abcd-1234-efgh-5678" in the system?

inputs.name: includeacknowledged
inputs.description: Set to True if you want to include acknowledged incidents in the data. By default, it is set to False.

inputs.name: endtime
inputs.description: Enter the end time of the data you want to get in milliseconds since midnight, January 1st, 1970 UTC (Unix timestamp format).

inputs.name: starttime
inputs.description: Enter the start time of the data you want to get in milliseconds since midnight, January 1st, 1970 UTC (Unix timestamp format).

inputs.name: locale
inputs.description: Choose the language for the returned text. Supported languages include German (de_DE), English UK (en_GB) which is Default, English US (en_US), Spanish ES (es_ES), Spanish LATAM (es_419), French (fr_FR), Italian (it_IT), Japanese (ja_JP), Korean (ko_KR), Portuguese BR (pt_BR), Chinese Simplified (zh_Hans), and Chinese Traditional (zh_Hant).

inputs.name: includegroupurl
inputs.description: Set to True to include links to the incident in the Threat Visualizer. Requires a valid FQDN value for the queried instance. By default, it is set to False. This is recommended when retrieving information to display to an end user.

inputs.name: did
inputs.description: Enter the identification number of a device in the Darktrace system to include incidents for.

inputs.name: sid
inputs.description: Enter the identification number of a subnet in the Darktrace system to include incidents for.

inputs.name: excludesid
inputs.description: Enter the identification number of a subnet in the Darktrace system to exclude incidents for.

inputs.name: maxscore
inputs.description: Set the maximum allowed score for an incident to be returned. It works like the slider filter on the Threat Tray. Accepts values between 0 and 100.

inputs.name: minscore
inputs.description: Set the minimum allowed score for an incident to be returned. It works like the slider filter on the Threat Tray. Accepts values between 0 and 100.

inputs.name: groupid
inputs.description: Enter a unique identifier for an AI Analyst incident. If provided, it will ignore other filter parameters and only return the specified incidents.

inputs.name: uuid
inputs.description: Enter a unique identifier for an AI Analyst incident event. If provided and groupID is not specified, it will ignore other filter parameters and only return incidents containing the specified ids.

settings.QueryInputs:uuid:Type:Name: String
settings.QueryInputs:uuid:Name: uuid
settings.QueryInputs:uuid:Description: Enter a unique identifier for an AI Analyst incident event. If provided and groupID is not specified, it will ignore other filter parameters and only return incidents containing the specified ids.
settings.QueryInputs:starttime:Type:Name: Int32
settings.QueryInputs:starttime:Name: starttime
settings.QueryInputs:starttime:Description: Enter the start time of the data you want to get in milliseconds since midnight, January 1st, 1970 UTC (Unix timestamp format).

settings.QueryInputs:sid:Name: sid
settings.QueryInputs:sid:Description: Enter the identification number of a subnet in the Darktrace system to include incidents for.
settings.QueryInputs:minscore:Type:Name: Int32
settings.QueryInputs:minscore:Name: minscore
settings.QueryInputs:minscore:Description: Set the minimum allowed score for an incident to be returned. It works like the slider filter on the Threat Tray. Accepts values between 0 and 100.
settings.QueryInputs:maxscore:Type:Name: Int32
settings.QueryInputs:maxscore:Name: maxscore
settings.QueryInputs:maxscore:Description: Set the maximum allowed score for an incident to be returned. It works like the slider filter on the Threat Tray. Accepts values between 0 and 100.

settings.QueryInputs:includegroupurl:Type:Name: Boolean
settings.QueryInputs:includegroupurl:Name: includegroupurl
settings.QueryInputs:includegroupurl:Description: Set to True to include links to the incident in the Threat Visualizer. Requires a valid FQDN value for the queried instance. By default, it is set to False. This is recommended when retrieving information to display to an end user.
settings.QueryInputs:includeacknowledged:Name: includeacknowledged
settings.QueryInputs:includeacknowledged:Descript: Set to True if you want to include acknowledged incidents in the data. By default, it is set to False.
settings.QueryInputs:groupid:Type:Name: String
settings.QueryInputs:groupid:Name: groupid
settings.QueryInputs:groupid:Description: Enter a unique identifier for an AI Analyst incident. If provided, it will ignore other filter parameters and only return the specified incidents.
settings.QueryInputs:excludesid:Type:Name: Int32
settings.QueryInputs:excludesid:Name: excludesid
settings.QueryInputs:excludesid:Description: Enter the identification number of a subnet in the Darktrace system to exclude incidents for.
settings.QueryInputs:endtime:Type:Name: Int32
settings.QueryInputs:endtime:Name: endtime
settings.QueryInputs:endtime:Description: Enter the end time of the data you want to get in milliseconds since midnight, January 1st, 1970 UTC (Unix timestamp format).
settings.QueryInputs:did:Type:Name: Int32
settings.QueryInputs:did:Name: did
settings.QueryInputs:did:Description: Enter the identification number of a device in the Darktrace system to include incidents for.

value.name: GetIncidentEvents
value.description:
An AI Analyst event contains information about a specific part of an investigation. Use this endpoint to obtain more in depth information about the events involved in an incident and filter them based on the available parameters. This endpoint is best used when you want more information about an incident group and know the groupid that starts with the 'g' character (e.g., g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633) and is 37 characters long.

**Note:** The timestamps and groupid provided in the examples are for illustration purposes only. Replace them with the appropriate timestamps and groupid based on your specific requirements. Make sure Unix timestamps for `starttime` and `endtime` correct for the time period you desire, as this is a common area to make a mistake. In the example URLs, replace `[instance]` with your actual instance information.

Use Cases:




### Examples:

1. `GET` details of the AI Analyst incident `uuid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633`:

    ```
    https://[instance]/aianalyst/incidentevents?groupid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633&includeincidenteventurl=true
    ```

2. `GET` details of all AI Analyst events for the incident `groupid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633` in French:

    ```
    https://[instance]/aianalyst/incidentevents?groupid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633&locale=fr_FR&includeincidenteventurl=true
    ```

3. `GET` all AI Analyst events for the device with `did=100` - including acknowledged events - for the 7 day period from 1st to 7th March 2022:

    ```
    https://[instance]/aianalyst/incidents?starttime=1646092800000&endtime=1646611200000&includeacknowledged=true&did=100&includeallpinned=false&includeincidenteventurl=true
    ```

4. `GET` AI Analyst events for SaaS activity that are part of critical incidents with a score >90 in the last 7 days:

    ```
    https://[instance]/aianalyst/incidentevents?mingroupscore=90&groupcritical=true&saasonly=true&includeincidenteventurl=true
    ```

**Note:** The timestamps and groupid provided in the examples are for illustration purposes only. Replace them with the appropriate timestamps and groupid based on your specific requirements. Make sure Unix timestamps for `starttime` and `endtime` correct for the time period you desire, as this is a common area to make a mistake. In the example URLs, replace `[instance]` with your actual instance information.

Use Cases:




### Examples:

1. `GET` details of the AI Analyst incident `uuid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633`:

2. `GET` details of all AI Analyst events for the incident `groupid=g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633` in French:

    ```

3. `GET` all AI Analyst events for the device with `did=100` - including acknowledged events - for the 7 day period from 1st to 7th March 2022:

4. `GET` AI Analyst events for SaaS activity that are part of critical incidents with a score >90 in the last 7 days:

value.name: GetCommentsForIncident
value.description:
The `/aianalyst/incident/comments` endpoint returns current comments on an AI Analyst event. It requires the `uuid` incident_id of an event to be provided.

A group id will begin with a 'g' character e.g. g04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633 and be 37 characters, it can be converted to the incident_id of the initial event
by removing the 'g' character leaving a 36 character incident_id e.g. 04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633.

Ensure you are not using the group id of an incident as is, they're typically used and returned by ai analyst (/aianalyst) endpoints.

The incident_id parameter is mandatory.

### Notes

+  An `incident_id` value corresponds to an event `uuid`, it can be found in:

   + The `id` field of an incident retrieved from incident events

   + The `uuid` field inside the `incidentEvents` array of an incident event retrieved from the incident groups endpoint.





### Example Request

`[instance]` in the following examples may be replaced with the instance IP or FQDN - for example, `https://10.0.0.1` or `https://euw1-1234-01.cloud.darktrace.com`


1.  `GET` comments for an AI Analyst event with `incident_id=04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633`:

    ```
    https://[instance]/aianalyst/incident/comments?incident_id=04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633
    ```
value.descriptionForModel:

by removing the 'g' character leaving a 36 character incident_id e.g. 04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633.

Ensure you are not using the group id of an incident as is, they're typically used and returned by ai analyst (/aianalyst) endpoints.

The incident_id parameter is mandatory.

### Notes

+  An `incident_id` value corresponds to an event `uuid`, it can be found in:

   + The `id` field of an incident retrieved from incident events

   + The `uuid` field inside the `incidentEvents` array of an incident event retrieved from the incident groups endpoint.





### Example Request

`[instance]` in the following examples may be replaced with the instance IP or FQDN - for example, `https://10.0.0.1` or `https://euw1-1234-01.cloud.darktrace.com`


1.  `GET` comments for an AI Analyst event with `incident_id=04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633`:

    ```
    https://[instance]/aianalyst/incident/comments?incident_id=04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633
    ```
examplePrompts: Get comments for "04a3f36e-4u8w-v9dh-x6lb-894778cf9633".
Get comments for this incident.
Has anyone added any comments?.

value.name: GetStats
value.description: Returns metadata on the investigations AI Analyst has performed. This data is used to populate the statistic in the homepage summary panel. This can be used to visualize how vast quantities of raw events have been distilled by Darktrace analysis, and how these events are relevant to tactics under the MITRE ATT&CK framework (which is returned in the `groupStats.mitreTactics` object).

This can be used to visualize how vast quantities of raw events have been distilled by Darktrace analysis, and how these events are relevant to tactics under the MITRE ATT&CK framework (which is returned in the `groupStats.mitreTactics` object).
examplePrompts: Show me AI Analyst statistics for the week
What Mitre Tactics has AI analyst been seeing?
Tell me how many events AI Analyst has looked through on my behalf

value.name: GetDetails
value.description:
The details endpoints is useful whenever you need information about specific connections or events including:
    Get information for connections to an external hostname,
    network connections, tcp, udp, blocked by respond ( antigena ), between devices
    notices, events associated to the device (for saas iaas paas etc all low level information is notices as there are no connections)
To review all connections Darktrace RESPOND/Network ( antigena ) attempted to action use blockedconnections=all. Use blockedconnections=failed for failed attempts. blockedconnections=true for ones that have not failed.









pbid is used to get any information related to a specific modelbreach connections or notices that triggered / caused it.
If not using a pbid, always use either count OR a short time range. Otherwise too much information will be returned.

GET the most recent 100 unusual connections for device with did=1

https://[instance]/details?did=1&count=100&eventtype=unusualconnection

Fetch all connections from December 1st 2020 (12:00:00) to December 2nd 2020 (00:00:00) for device with did=1:

https://[instance]/details?did=1&from=2020-12-01T12:00:00&to=2020-12-02

What are the most recent 20 events from a device with did=1 to a device with did=2:

https://[instance]/details?did=1&ddid=2&count=20

What caused the modelbreach model breach with pbid=1234:

https://[instance]/details?pbid=1234

GET the most recent 20 dns (which is port 53) connections for a device with did=3:

https://[instance]/details?destinationport=53&did=3&count=20

    notices, events associated to the device (for saas iaas paas etc all low level information is notices as there are no connections)
To review all connections Darktrace RESPOND/Network ( antigena ) attempted to action use blockedconnections=all. Use blockedconnections=failed for failed attempts. blockedconnections=true for ones that have not failed.









pbid is used to get any information related to a specific modelbreach connections or notices that triggered / caused it.
If not using a pbid, always use either count OR a short time range. Otherwise too much information will be returned.

GET the most recent 100 unusual connections for device with did=1

Fetch all connections from December 1st 2020 (12:00:00) to December 2nd 2020 (00:00:00) for device with did=1:

What are the most recent 20 events from a device with did=1 to a device with did=2:

What caused the modelbreach model breach with pbid=1234:

https://[instance]/details?pbid=1234

GET the most recent 20 dns (which is port 53) connections for a device with did=3:

https://[instance]/details?destinationport=53&did=3&count=20
examplePrompts: Do you know about any connections between devices 1400 and destination device ddid 1401 ?
Have you seen any connections between devices 1400 and 1401 ?
Has there been any unusual connections from device 29 ?
Can you provide information on any interactions between device 2400 and destination device ddid 2401?
Have there been any connections involving devices 2400 and 2401 recently?
Are there any notable events involving device 45 and external hostname "example.com"?
Get me events that occurred between those 2 devices?

inputs.name: count
inputs.description: Specifies the maximum number of items to return.

inputs.name: ddid
inputs.description: Identification number of a destination device modelled in the Darktrace system to restrict data to.

inputs.name: destinationport
inputs.description: This filter can be used to filter the returned data by destination port.

inputs.name: did
inputs.description: Identification number of a device modelled in the Darktrace system.

inputs.name: eventtype
inputs.description: Specifies an type of event to return details for. Possible values are connection, unusualconnection, newconnection, notice, devicehistory, modelbreach.

inputs.name: externalhostname
inputs.description: Specifies an external hostname to return details for.

inputs.name: from
inputs.description: Start time of data to return in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format.

inputs.name: fulldevicedetails
inputs.description: Returns the full device detail objects for all devices referenced by data in an API response. Use of this parameter will alter the JSON structure of the API response for certain calls.

inputs.name: odid
inputs.description: Other Device ID - Identification number of a device modelled in the Darktrace system to restrict data to. Typically used with ddid and odid to specify device pairs regardless of source/destination.

inputs.name: port
inputs.description: This filter can be used to filter the returned data by source or destination port.

inputs.name: sourceport
inputs.description: This filter can be used to filter the returned data by source port.

inputs.name: to
inputs.description: End time of data to return in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format.

inputs.name: uid
inputs.description: Specifies a connection UID to return.

inputs.name: responsedata
inputs.description: When given the name of a top-level field or object, restricts the returned JSON to only that field or object.

inputs.name: blockedconnections
inputs.description: Filters the results to connections Darktrace RESPOND attempted to action. Valid values are `all`,`failed`,`true`.

value.name: GetEndpointDetails
value.description:
Use this endpoint to gather detailed information about external domains, hostnames, or endpoints that Darktrace has encountered. This is primarily used to investigate external systems, such as unusual IPs or websites. For information about internal hosts within your network, use the `/devices` endpoint instead.

`/endpointdetails` returns location, IP address, and (optionally) device connection information for external IPs, hostnames, and domain names. It helps you gather intel about external endpoints and the devices that have interacted with them.

Use Cases:






### Notes

+ The "popularity" score = 100 – (IP or domain) rarity score.

+ For hostname queries, `additionalinfo=true` will add an `ips` object and a `locations` object with details of the IP addresses Darktrace has seen associated with the hostname and the physical locations of those IPs where derivable.

+ Queries for IPs that are internal (or treated as such) will return `"name": "internal_ip",` in the response and different key/value fields.

### Example Request

`[instance]` in the following examples may be replaced with the instance IP or FQDN - for example, `https://10.0.0.1` or `https://euw1-1234-01.cloud.darktrace.com`


1. `GET` details for 8.8.8.8:

    ```
    https://[instance]/endpointdetails?ip=8.8.8.8
    ```

2. `GET` details for darktrace.com, including a list of devices that have connected to it:

    ```
    https://[instance]/endpointdetails?hostname=darktrace.com&devices=true
    ```

`/endpointdetails` returns location, IP address, and (optionally) device connection information for external IPs, hostnames, and domain names. It helps you gather intel about external endpoints and the devices that have interacted with them.

    ```

    ```
examplePrompts: Retrieve location and IP address details for the external hostname "example.com."

value.name: Summarystatistics
value.description:
`/summarystatistics` returns simple statistics on device counts, processed bandwidth and the number of active Darktrace RESPOND actions.






### MITRE ATT&CK Framework

The homepage summary visualizes how vast quantities of raw events have been distilled by Darktrace analysis, and how these events are relevant to _tactics_ under the MITRE ATT&CK framework.

For model breaches and raw events, this data is retrieved from the `/summarystatistics` endpoint with the `mitreTactics` parameter.

For AI Analyst, this data is returned in the `groupStats.mitreTactics` object returned from the `/aianalyst/stats` endpoint.
value.descriptionForModel:
`/summarystatistics` returns simple statistics on device counts, processed bandwidth and the number of active Darktrace RESPOND actions.






### MITRE ATT&CK Framework

The homepage summary visualizes how vast quantities of raw events have been distilled by Darktrace analysis, and how these events are relevant to _tactics_ under the MITRE ATT&CK framework.

For model breaches and raw events, this data is retrieved from the `/summarystatistics` endpoint with the `mitreTactics` parameter.

For AI Analyst, this data is returned in the `groupStats.mitreTactics` object returned from the `/aianalyst/stats` endpoint.
examplePrompts: Get me a summary of what Darktrace has seen and done
Fetch a summary of Darktrace activity
Get me Darktraces statistics
Get the system information displayed on the homepage

inputs.name: responsedata
inputs.description: When given the name of a top-level field or object, restricts the returned JSON to only that field or object.

inputs.name: eventtype
inputs.description: Changes the format of data to return numeric event counts for any of the four categories of events and/or three types (see above).

inputs.name: to
inputs.description: End time of data to return in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format.

inputs.name: hours
inputs.description: The number of hour intervals from the end time (or current time) to return. Requires `eventtype`.

inputs.name: csensor
inputs.description: When `true`, only bandwidth statistics are returned for Darktrace/Endpoint cSensor agents. When `false`, statistics returned are for Darktrace/Network bandwidth

inputs.name: mitreTactics
inputs.description: When `true`, alters the returned data to display total processed raw events and analysis outputs, broken down by MITRE ATT&CK Framework tactic.

inputs.name: endtime
inputs.description: End Unix epoch time format time of data to return.

value.name: GetEmailBy{uuid}
value.description:
For the Darktrace Email platform return the summary of the specified email.

Short hand tags are difficult to understand, you can use the following friendly name mapping to improve readability:

    - out of character (value: "ah")
    - credential harvesting (value: "ch")
    - extortion (value: "ex")
    - phishing attachment (value: "pa")
    - spam (value: "sp")
    - phishing link (value: "pl")
    - solicitation (value: "so")
    - spoofing indicators (value: "ss")
    - vip impersonation (value: "vi")
    - malware or ransomware (value: "mr")
value.descriptionForModel:
For the Darktrace Email platform return the summary of the specified email.

Short hand tags are difficult to understand, you can use the following friendly name mapping to improve readability:

    - out of character (value: "ah")
    - credential harvesting (value: "ch")
    - extortion (value: "ex")
    - phishing attachment (value: "pa")
    - spam (value: "sp")
    - phishing link (value: "pl")
    - solicitation (value: "so")
    - spoofing indicators (value: "ss")
    - vip impersonation (value: "vi")
    - malware or ransomware (value: "mr")
